contentrichtext.text: '''Quantum radar''' is a hypothetical remote-sensing method based on quantum entanglement. One possible implementation of such technology has been developed and patented<ref>{{ cite web | url = https://publications.european-patent-office.org/PublicationServer/documentpdf.jsp?PN=EP1750145%20EP%201750145&iDocId=6181555&iepatch=.pdf | title = European patent number EP1750145 | accessdate = 2007-03-17 }}</ref> by defense contractor [[Lockheed Martin]].<ref>{{ cite news | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/story/0,,2027298,00.html | title = US defence contractor looks for quantum leap in radar research | accessdate = 2007-03-17 | work=The Guardian | location=London | first=David | last=Adam | date=2007-03-06}}</ref> It intends to create a radar system which provides a better resolution and higher detail than classical radar can provide. The technology is hoped to work by using [[photon entanglement]] to allow several entangled photons to function as if a shorter wavelength was used to allow detection of small details while having an overall longer group wavelength that allows long distance transmission.<ref>Marco Lanzagorta, ''[http://www.amazon.com/Quantum-Radar-Synthesis-Lectures-Computing/dp/1608458261 Quantum Radar]'', Morgan & Claypool (2011).</ref> According to a recent and controversial (but not yet known to have been disproven) theory, any such remote-sensing device (including, but not limited to Lockheed Martin's planned implementation of technology), using quantum (photon) entanglement, may be able to extract meaningful information from specific regions of [[hyperspace]]. A [http://arxiv.org/abs/1101.2223 hypothetical research paper] on the subject suggests that photon-entanglement, combined with interferometry, can possibly be used to remote-sense distant quantum properties of past, present or even future hypersurfaces of spacetime. The paper is based on exploiting causal and relativistic loopholes<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://feny.idokep.hu/quantum/Delayed-Choice-Quantum-Eraser-Remote-Sensing-Hyperspace.pdf | title = Causal and relativistic loopholes in a Delayed-choice Quantum Eraser Experiment | accessdate = 2011-01-04 }}</ref> supposedly found in the 1999 realization of the [[Delayed choice quantum eraser|Delayed Choice Quantum Eraser]] experiment by Yoon-Ho Kim, R. Yu, S.P. Kulik, Y.H. Shih, designed by Marlan O. Scully. One advantage of a quantum radar system is that it automatically detects deceptive jamming, which might otherwise go unnoticed.<ref>[http://www.technologyreview.com/view/508826/quantum-imaging-technique-heralds-unjammable-aircraft-detection/ "Quantum Imaging Technique Heralds Unjammable Aircraft Detection."]</ref> == References == <references/> == External links == * [http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/story/0,,2027298,00.html US defence contractor looks for quantum leap in radar research] * [https://publications.european-patent-office.org/PublicationServer/documentpdf.jsp?PN=EP1750145%20EP%201750145&iDocId=6181555&iepatch=.pdf Patent for Radar systems and methods using entangled quantum particles] * [http://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1101/1101.2223.pdf Remote-Sensing Quantum Hyperspace by Entangled Photon Interferometry] [[Category:Radar]] [[Category:Lockheed Martin]]
